block.p: Ivory Coast Uprising Ousts Ruler After Disputed Vote Thousands of people poured into the streets of Abidjan in a revolt against the military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, who had declared himself the winner of a disputed presidential election. The whereabouts of Mr. Guei, who seized power in a coup last Christmas Eve, was unclear. The general's main election opponent, Laurent Gbagbo, declared himself president and the army chief said the military backed him. But at least one political party called for a new election.

Ivory Coast Uprising Ousts Ruler After Disputed Vote Thousands of people poured into the streets of Abidjan in a revolt against the military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, who had declared himself the winner of a disputed presidential election. The whereabouts of Mr. Guei, who seized power in a coup last Christmas Eve, was unclear. The general's main election opponent, Laurent Gbagbo, declared himself president and the army chief said the military backed him. But at least one political party called for a new election.
A Respite in the Mideast Relative calm prevailed on the streets of the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the third day.

President Clinton, who is trying to get Yasir Arafat and Ehud Barak to Washington next week to try to restart the peace process, praised the Israeli prime minister but verged on blaming the Palestinian leader for not reining in violence.
Yemen Bombing Inquiry President Ali Abdullah Saleh said ''preliminary investigations'' indicated that at least one of the two men who carried out the suicide bombing attack on the Cole was Egyptian.
A Pentagon intelligence analyst resigned one day after the bombing of the Cole, complaining that his warning about an imminent threat in the region was ignored, officials said.

Gore's Russia Deal Called Legal A 1995 deal signed by Vice President Al Gore and Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the former Russian prime minister, allowing Russia to sell weapons to Iran without the United States imposing economic sanctions, was legal and did not threaten security, State Department officials told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Yugoslavia Heads Back to U.N. The American ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, said after a meeting of Balkan leaders that Yugoslavia would soon apply to rejoin the United Nations.

Peru Spy Chief Sought President Alberto K. Fujimori ordered the military to arrest his former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, whose return from a monthlong exile threw the country into turmoil. Opposition leaders hailed the arrest order.

California Is No Longer A Sure Thing for Gore Hard campaigning by Gov. George W. Bush and the Republican Party has tightened the presidential race in California, which Vice President Al Gore -- and most political analysts -- at one time had solidly in the Democrats' column. And the Green Party candidate, Ralph Nader, also figures in the erosion of Mr. Gore's once double-digit lead over Mr. Bush.
Mr. Nader accused Mr. Gore of repeatedly breaking promises to clean up the environment, help the poor and reform the government.

Mr. Gore, campaigning in his home state, Tennessee, framed his differences with Mr. Bush on education by emphasizing his commitment to public schools and describing Mr. Bush's proposals as ''half-measures'' and his Texas record as ''hollow.''
Mr. Gore is showing surprising strength in Florida among elderly and independent voters, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.

Bush Makes Case to Floridians Gov. George W. Bush made an aggressive appeal to elderly voters in Florida, pitching his Social Security and Medicare plans and accusing Vice President Al Gore of employing scare tactics.

Maneuvering on Tax Changes President Clinton and Congressional Republicans narrowed differences on a tax-cut package that includes relief for small businesses and a rise in the minimum wage, but hurdles to a final deal remained.

Germ Terror Defense Faulted The Henry L. Stimson Center, a nonprofit public policy research group, said that the threat of terrorism involving chemical and germ weapons had been exaggerated and that much of the government's response had been wasteful and ill-conceived.

Poem's Authorship Challenged A Vassar English professor says Clement Clarke Moore probably did not write the enduring 19th century Christmas poem ''Account of a Visit from St. Nicholas,'' better known as ''The Night Before Christmas.'' Rather, he said, it appears to have been the work of Henry Livingston Jr. of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

Mrs. Clinton to Return Money From Muslim Event Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would return $50,000 in political contributions received at a fund-raiser sponsored by a Muslim organization based in California. The group's president has praised a United Nations resolution that he says allowed for the use of armed force by Palestinians against Israel; other group members have been accused of making anti-Semitic remarks.
Fugitive Seized in Austria Sholam Weiss, 46, a Brooklyn-born businessman sentenced in absentia to 845 years in an insurance fraud scheme, was arrested in Austria.

Saving Cardiac Arrest Victims Two studies, one conducted at casinos and the other on airliners, found that many people who suffer cardiac arrest can be saved if ordinary people are trained to use defibrillators to shock them back to life.

Study Faults Fossil Fuels Greenhouse gases mainly from fossil fuels are altering the atmosphere in ways that affect climate, an international scientific panel said, and it is likely that they have ''contributed substantially to the observed warming over the last 50 years.''
Altered Corn Found in Japan A Japanese consumer group said StarLink bioengineered corn, which is not approved for humans, had made its way from the United States into cornmeal made in Japan.
Yanks Lead Series, 3-1 The Yankees beat the Mets at Shea Stadium, 3-2, to move to within one game of their third straight World Series championship. Game 5 is at Shea tonight.
N.B.A. Levies Huge Penalty The Minnesota Timberwolves were fined $3.5 million and stripped of first-round draft picks for five years for violating salary-cap rules.

AT&T Breakup Plan AT&T said it would break itself into four parts, with four publicly traded stocks. The move is a pullback from an expensive three-year effort to become the first one-stop shop selling long-distance, wireless, cable television and Internet services across the nation as a single package with a single bill.

Bond Markets Send Signal High-yield bonds issued by corporations have plunged in price and rocketed in yield, with the Merrill Lynch high-yield corporate bond index carrying a yield of 13.24 percent. Some see the bond markets as signaling that America should be more worried about a slowdown than prospects for higher inflation.

Selloff in Technology Stocks The Nasdaq fell 190.22 points, or 5.6 percent, to 3,229.57; the S.& P. 500 dropped 66.59 points, or 2.4 percent, to 10,326.48; and the Dow fell 66.59, less than 1 percent, to 10,326.48.
Editorials: Mr. Nader's electoral mischief; a better approach to drug offenders; Tina Rosenberg on fighting poverty.
